columns.text: In this problem, we need to solve for the appropriate bid price that we should submit for the given project.

The bid price refers to how much a firm is willing to pay to get a certain project. In situations like this, it is important to set a price that is both competitive, which means that it is not too high, but also still profitable.

To start, we first need to solve for the operating cash flow of the project. In order to do this, we will use the formula for the net present value, but we will set the net present value as zero. The formula for the net present value is this:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=-\text{Initial investment}-\text{Initial net working capital}\\
&-\text{Present value of land}+\text{Operating cash flow} \times \text{Annuity factor}\\
&-\text{Present net working capital} \times \text{Annuity factor}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{After-tax salvage value of land and asset}+\text{Initial and present net working capital}}{(1+\text{Required return})^\text{time}}
\end{aligned}$$

Now, we need to solve for the after-tax salvage value of the equipment. For this, we will simply multiply how much we will be able to sell the equipment at the end of the project by one minus the tax rate. Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value of equipment}&=\$450,000\times (1-0.23)\\[15 pt]
&=\$346,500
\end{aligned}$$

The after-tax salvage value of the equipment is $\$346,500$

Next, we need to solve for the present net working capital. In the problem, it says that you need an additional amount of $\$50,000$ every year. This means that the present net working capital is simply this amount times the remaining number of years which is $4$. The value will then be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present net working capital}&=\$50,000 \times 4\\[15 pt]
&=\$200,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for the remainder of the project is $\$200,000$

Then, we need to identify the annuity factors that we will use. For this, we will use an annuity table. 

For the operating cash flow, we will use the $10\%$ required return and the time of $5$ years. This will give us an annuity factor of $3.60478$.

For the present net working capital, we will use the same required return but the time is $4$ years. This will give us an annuity factor of $3.03735$

Now that we have the values, we can substitute them to the formula in Step 3. Take note that the net present value should be zero in this situation.

$$\begin{aligned}
0&=-\$5,100,000-\$425,000-\$1,125,000\\
&+(\text{Operating cash flow} \times 3.60478)\\
&-\$200,000 \times 3.03735\\
&+\dfrac{\$346,500+\$1,295,000+\$425,000+\$200,000}{(1+0.10)^5}
\end{aligned}$$

Simplifying the values that can be added together, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
0&=-\$6,650,000+(\text{Operating cash flow}\times 3.60478)\\
&-\$607,470+\$1,407,318.18\\[15 pt]
0&=-\$5,850,151.82+(\text{Operating cash flow}\times 3.60478)
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the unknown on one side then divide both sides by $3.60478$

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\text{Operating cash flow} \times 3.60478}{3.60478}&=\dfrac{\$5,850,151.82}{3.60478}\\[15 pt]
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$1,622,887.34
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for this project is $\$1,622,887.34$
For this, the variable cost is how much it costs to produce a single stamp. In the problem, it states that each stamp costs $0.38$ cents which translates to $\$0.0038$

For the depreciation, simply divide the initial investment  by the number of years.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\dfrac{\$5,100,000}{5}\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,020,000
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for this project is $\$1,020,000$

Substituting the values to the formula in Step 10, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,622,887.34&=[(\text{Price}-\$0.0038) \times 100,000,000] \times (1-0.23)\\
&+0.23 \times \$1,020,000
\end{aligned}$$

Distribute the $100,000,000$ to the terms inside the parentheses then simplify the other values.

$$\begin{aligned}
\$1,622,887.34&=(100,000,000\times \text{Price}-\$380,000) \times (0.77)\\
&+\$234,600\\[15 pt]
\$1,388,287.34&=(100,000,000\times \text{Price}-\$380,000) \times (0.77)
\end{aligned}$$

Isolate the unknown then divide both sides by $100,000,000$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}&=\dfrac{\$1,802,970.57+\$380,000}{100,000,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$0.021829
\end{aligned}$$

This means that the bid price that we should submit is $\$0.021829$
